private_information: I control one manipulator that can pick up and put down blocks
I can unstack a top block from a stack and I can stack a held block onto another clear block
block_agent_1.goal: Participate in executing the prescribed sequence of block world actions and report local observations and any ambiguities.

private_information: I control a second manipulator that can pick up and put down blocks
I follow the given action sequence when it is my turn and report local observations and any ambiguities
block_agent_2.goal: Participate in executing the prescribed sequence of block world actions and report local observations and any ambiguities.

private_information: I coordinate inputs from the two block agents and must produce a single PDDL domain and problem suitable for the FastDownwards solver
orchestrator.goal: Integrate agent reports into a consistent Blocks World PDDL domain and problem that encodes the initial state and the final arrangement after the action sequence; produce domain and problem enclosed in <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags targeting FastDownwards.

public_information: Standard Blocks World rules: only the top block of a stack may be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
The blocks present are: A B C D E F G H I J.
Initial arrangement: A on F, B on C, C on E, D on table, E on G, F on H, G on D, H on B, I on table, J on I.
Explicit initial stacks from top to bottom are: Stack1 top-to-bottom: A F H B C E G D. Stack2 top-to-bottom: J I.

The agents execute this action sequence in the given global order: 1 unstack(A,F), 2 stack(A,J), 3 unstack(F,H), 4 putdown(F), 5 pickup(F), 6 stack(F,H), 7 unstack(F,H), 8 putdown(F), 9 pickup(F), 10 stack(F,H), 11 unstack(F,H), 12 stack(F,A), 13 unstack(H,B), 14 putdown(H), 15 unstack(B,C), 16 stack(B,C), 17 pickup(H), 18 stack(H,F), 19 unstack(B,C), 20 stack(B,C), 21 unstack(H,F), 22 stack(H,F), 23 unstack(H,F), 24 stack(H,B), 25 unstack(F,A), 26 putdown(F), 27 unstack(H,B), 28 stack(H,F), 29 unstack(B,C), 30 stack(B,C), 31 unstack(A,J), 32 stack(A,H), 33 unstack(A,H), 34 putdown(A), 35 unstack(B,C), 36 putdown(B), 37 unstack(H,F), 38 stack(H,C), 39 pickup(B), 40 putdown(B), 41 unstack(H,C), 42 stack(H,J), 43 pickup(F), 44 stack(F,A), 45 pickup(B), 46 stack(B,F), 47 unstack(H,J), 48 putdown(H), 49 unstack(C,E), 50 stack(C,H).

Task: using the initial configuration and the action sequence, derive the final arrangement of every block and encode the initial state and goal state in a PDDL domain and problem suitable for FastDownwards.

report.system_prompt: You are a blocks-world manipulator agent. Provide a concise natural-language report of your local observations, any preconditions you assume for the actions you perform, and any ambiguities you detect. Do not produce PDDL domain or problem files.
report.prompt: Your name is block_agent_1. You have access to the public information about the blocks and the global action sequence. Describe in plain text which actions you executed or observed from your perspective, any conditions required for those actions to be valid, and flag any ambiguous references or missing information that would prevent deterministic execution.

report.system_prompt: You are a blocks-world manipulator agent. Provide a concise natural-language report of your local observations, any preconditions you assume for the actions you perform, and any ambiguities you detect. Do not produce PDDL domain or problem files.
report.prompt: Your name is block_agent_2. You have access to the public information about the blocks and the global action sequence. Describe in plain text which actions you executed or observed from your perspective, any conditions required for those actions to be valid, and flag any ambiguous references or missing information that would prevent deterministic execution.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert orchestrator for multi-agent Blocks World problems. Integrate agents' reports and produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agent actions distinct where relevant. The PDDL must encode the standard blocks world operators pickup putdown stack unstack with STRIPS semantics and should include the initial state as stated in the public information and the goal that matches the final arrangement derived from the action sequence.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the two agents' natural-language reports. Use the public information initial configuration and the explicit action sequence to derive the final arrangement of blocks. Then produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem compatible with FastDownwards that encodes: objects A B C D E F G H I J, initial state matching the provided initial arrangement, and a goal state matching the final arrangement you derived. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. If there are naming ambiguities between agent reports, reconcile them without changing object identities.
